Literature Review: FLASH radiotherapy (FLASH-RT) has emerged as a groundbreaking approach in cancer treatment, offering the potential to revolutionize the field of radiation oncology. This novel technique, characterized by the delivery of ultrahigh dose rates in extremely short time frames, has garnered significant attention due to its ability to spare normal tissues while maintaining tumor control efficacy. The FLASH effect, as it has come to be known, represents a paradigm shift in our understanding of radiobiology and holds promise for improving patient outcomes across a wide range of cancer types.The concept of FLASH-RT was first introduced by Favaudon et al. in 2014, who demonstrated that ultrahigh dose rate irradiation could significantly reduce lung fibrosis in mice without compromising tumor control [1]. This seminal study sparked a surge of interest in the field, leading to numerous investigations aimed at elucidating the mechanisms underlying the FLASH effect and exploring its potential clinical applications.One of the key features of FLASH-RT is its ability to deliver radiation doses at rates exceeding 40 Gy/s, compared to conventional radiotherapy, which typically operates at dose rates of 0.03-0.05 Gy/s [2]. This ultra-rapid delivery is thought to be crucial for inducing the FLASH effect, as studies have shown that the normal tissue sparing is lost when the overall treatment time exceeds 500 ms [3].The mechanisms underlying the FLASH effect remain a subject of intense investigation. Several hypotheses have been proposed to explain the differential response between normal tissues and tumors. One prominent theory suggests that the rapid depletion of oxygen in normal tissues during FLASH irradiation may play a critical role in protecting healthy cells [4]. This 'oxygen depletion hypothesis' posits that the ultrahigh dose rate leads to a transient state of hypoxia in normal tissues, rendering them more radioresistant. In contrast, tumors, which are often already hypoxic, do not benefit from this protective effect.Another proposed mechanism involves the differential activation of DNA damage response pathways in normal and tumor cells. Vozenin et al. demonstrated that FLASH-RT induces a distinct pattern of DNA damage and repair compared to conventional radiotherapy, potentially explaining the observed normal tissue sparing [5]. Furthermore, recent studies have suggested that FLASH-RT may modulate the immune response differently than conventional radiotherapy, potentially enhancing anti-tumor immunity while mitigating normal tissue inflammation [6].The potential clinical applications of FLASH-RT are vast and exciting. Preclinical studies have demonstrated the FLASH effect in various organ systems, including the lung, brain, and gastrointestinal tract [7]. These findings suggest that FLASH-RT could be particularly beneficial in treating cancers in radiation-sensitive areas, where normal tissue toxicity often limits the deliverable dose.One of the most promising applications of FLASH-RT is in the treatment of brain tumors. A study by Montay-Gruel et al. showed that FLASH-RT could effectively treat glioblastoma in mice while preserving cognitive function, a significant improvement over conventional radiotherapy [8]. This finding has important implications for improving the quality of life of brain cancer patients, who often suffer from cognitive decline as a result of treatment.Despite the exciting potential of FLASH-RT, several challenges must be addressed before it can be widely implemented in clinical practice. One major hurdle is the development of suitable technology for delivering ultrahigh dose rates in a controlled and precise manner. Current efforts are focused on adapting existing linear accelerators and exploring novel particle beam technologies, such as proton and electron FLASH [9].Another important consideration is the need for robust dosimetry and quality assurance protocols specific to FLASH-RT. The ultrahigh dose rates used in FLASH-RT present unique challenges for accurate dose measurement and verification, necessitating the development of new dosimetry techniques and standards [10].As research in FLASH-RT continues to advance, it is becoming increasingly clear that this technology has the potential to redefine the field of radiation oncology. By offering the possibility of reducing normal tissue toxicity without compromising tumor control, FLASH-RT could significantly improve the therapeutic index for a wide range of cancers. However, further research is needed to fully elucidate the mechanisms underlying the FLASH effect and to translate these promising preclinical findings into clinical practice. As we stand on the brink of this exciting new era in radiotherapy, it is clear that FLASH-RT represents a paradigm shift in our approach to cancer treatment, with the potential to significantly improve outcomes for cancer patients worldwide.
